content: Nils Wetzstein is a consultant for infectious diseases at University Hospital Frankfurt (UHF). He has a keen interest in mycobacterial diseases and his research is primarily focussed on NTM infections. The working group of mycobacterial diseases at UHF uses a variety of bacteriological, epidemiological and bioinformatical methods to improve clinical management and patient care for MTB and NTM infected patients.

content: Florian Maurer is a medical doctor trained in Germany, Switzerland and South Africa. He is a Professor of Medical Microbiology at the University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf and holds both German and Swiss specialist degrees in Clinical Microbiology. He has a strong background in public health, bacteriology, antimicrobial resistance, drug susceptibility testing and chemotherapy of infections due to highly drug-resistant pathogens. He offers regular educational activities on clinical microbiology, antimicrobial resistance and antibiotic stewardship to medical students and infectious diseases professionals. His current research interests include the structure-function relationship of determinants conferring virulence and drug-resistance in mycobacteria, in particular in highly drug-resistant strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium abscessus.

content: Stefan Niemann is Professor at the Research Center Borstel, Molecular and Experimental Mycobacteriology in Germany. He is molecular biologist with a large experience in molecular characterization of M. tuberculosis complex isolates. His research interests are focused on the development of rapid diagnostics, the epidemiology of tuberculosis (TB), mechanisms of development and spread of resistance in clinical M. tuberculosis complex (MTBC) isolates, the microevolution in clinical MTBC isolates, the global population structure/evolution of the pathogen, and on the pathobiology and host-pathogen interaction. The following links provide more information on his research goals https://fz-borstel.de/index.php/en/sitemap/priority-research-area-infections-prof-dr-ulrich-schaible/molecular-and-experimental-mycobacteriology-prof-dr-stefan-niemann/mission#innercontent https://www.tbsequel.org/personnel/stefan-niemann/ Based on his achievements, he has been awarded the Eva and Klaus Grohe Prize of the Berlin-Brandenburg Academy of Sciences and Humanities in 2011, the Main Prize of the German Society for Hygiene and Microbiology in 2016, the DZIF Prize for Clinical Translational Infection Research in 2019, and the Gardner Middlebrook Award in 2021. He became W3 Professor for Molecular and Experimental Mycobacteriology at the University of LÃ¼beck in 2014, one out of eight Schleswig-Holstein-Excellence-Chairs in 2016, and Visiting Professor of the University of Namibia in 2017.

content: Thomas Kohl works as postdoctoral researcher in the Molecular and Experimental Mycobacteriology group at the Research Center Borstel. There, he established the NGS sequencing lab and the respective Bioinformatics procedures and IT infrastructure, and is managing the continued operation of the NGS unit with a throughput of more than 8000 samples annually. He was involved in several key studies establishing the use of whole genome sequencing for the analysis of bacterial pathogens such as the M. tuberculosis complex, M. chimaera, and S. maltophilia.

content: Margo Diricks is postdoctoral researcher and bioinformatics research scientist in the Molecular and Experimental Mycobacteriology group at the Research Center Borstel, Germany. She is interested in molcular techniques, antimicrobial resistance and mycobacteria. Currently she is involved in different projects regarding molecular typing of bacteria, such as Haemophilus influenzae and M. abscessus. For the latter, she developed a cgMLST theme to detect dominant circulating clones and is curator of the publicly available MLST scheme at pubmlst.org.

M. avium complex M. avium complex (MAC) consists of several species, the most important ones being M. avium, M. intracellulare and M. chimaera cit. They are all slow gowing mycobacteria (SGM) with different ranges of pathogenicity cit. IN the past, this complex was designated as M. avium-intracellulare complex (MAI) Cit. Mycobacterium genavense Etymology The term genavense is derived from the swiss city Geneva, where the bacterium was firstly isolated from a case series of HIV patients with a highly immunocompromised state cit.
Microbiology M. genavense is a slow-growing mycobacterium that has a predilection for the gastgrointestinal tract cit. Its cultivation is fastiduous and classic solid culture media for mycobacteria remain negative quite often cit.
Epidemiology Infections due to M. genavense are quite rare. A recent meta-anlysis could summarize XXX cases in HIV positive and negative individuals cit. Mainly cases were described in Europe, but the bacterium seems to be distributed across the whole world cit.
Clinical Manifestations  disseminated infections  Treatment  a macrolide containing regimen  Literature

content:
Introduction: M. abscessus is a multi-drug resistant rapid-growing mycobacterium that causes difficult to treat infections. Especially, patients with predisposing lung conditions, such as cystic fibrosis, are the ones most at risk. It has also been involved in nosocomial transmission during surgical procedures. However, the existence of so-called dominant circulating clones that exist globally and are associated with higher mortality and morbidity have lead to the assumption that inter-human transmission (direct or via fomites) takes place in these NTM. It has been stipulated that this NTM undergoes similar evolutional changes as M. tuberculosis complex before becoming a exclusively pathogenic mycobacterium. Objectives: Investigation of the genomic landscape of M. abscessus in Germany, especially among CF-patients and the search for the dominant circulating clones in a German collective. Methods: Clinical and epidemiological data-analysis, whole genome sequencing, genotypic drug susceptibility testing.
Status: Data analysis completed, manuscript under review European Nucleotide Archive
Microreact project
summary: Investigation of the molecular epidemiology of *M. abscessus* in German CF and non-CF patients.
title: MOMA_CF

content:
Introduction: M. avium complex is the predominant slow-growing mycobacterium in Europe and North America and consists â among others â of the species M. avium, M. intracellulare and M. chimaera. The latter has been involved in a global outbreak of infections in patients that underwent cardiosurgical interventions. Here, contaminated heater-cooler machines could be identified as point infection source. All three species are present in the environment and have been isolated from water sources in patients homes. However, human-to-human transmission has not been established so far. In CF-patients, M. avium complex is the NTM second most frequently isolated in Europe. If there are dominant circulating clones, as has been described in M. abscessus, remains unclear until now.

Objectives: Investigation of the genomic epidemiology of M. avium complex in multiple centers in Germany. Methods: Clinical and epidemiological data-analysis, whole genome sequencing, genotypic drug susceptibility testing.
Status: Currently recruiting
